Posts.Content: The USA prescribe Claritin (generic Loratidine) which is a one-a-day antihistamine, which together with regular paracetamol, does seem to help with the bone pain. I learnt this with being on a Facebook group for Lymphoma, where these jabs are very often needed.  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: white blood cell injections

Posts.Content: Hi, the USA, for Lymphoma bone ache problems with the G-CSF, prescribe Claritin (generic name Loratidine), it’s a one a day antihistamine but does seem to help together with regular paracetamol.  Hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Results Are In :)

Posts.Content: My GP surgery now refuse to prescribe antihistamines which can be bought cheaply. I use Claritin (generic name Loratidine) for bone and joint pain (as well as for post nasal drip etc) and yes it works. But I now buy it in as much bulk and as cheaply as I can!  As for the argument about paracetamol, I’ve had this many times; the GP prescription amount quoted is for 200 tablets, you can’t actually buy that for the stated £1 ever, anywhere! And there is a problem with the amount allowed, by shops or pharmacies, it would have people, struggling with chronic pain, to get to their local shop almost daily, to get the ‘allowed’ amount.  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: HNS England - Prescribing Restrictions on Some Over The Counter D...

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a mx with permanent implant, surgery was in the afternoon, my bc surgeon wanted enough time on her operating list to make sure she got the positioning and size etc as good as possible but had to go back to theatre the following afternoon as I’d bled and got haematomas ( blood clots) even behind the implant, but still went home after a 2 night stay, together with 2 drains. One came out a few days later, the other stayed for 16 days as they were concerned about the amount I bled post op and was still draining.  But all is ok now! It’s just over a month afterwards, and things are settling nicely.  A combination of lack of sleep and hospital food sent me home, to be honest! But I had family to care for me when I got home and a good 9 hours sleep plus afternoon naps were the order of the day for the next week!  Hope all goes well for you Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy op help

Posts.Content: Will be thinking of you, Leolady, and hoping nobody follows you around! Also hope the se’s are kind to you and everyone..... Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo farts

Posts.Content: Hi Ginacarla, i was offered Cipla once but refused it, got my regular pharmacy to order Accord. They began to make a fuss a couple of months later so I got my GP to put ‘please supply Accord brand’ on my repeat, which seems to have worked. I have built up a couple of months of stock so if they need to order I still have plenty. Oddly, GP checked on his list of brands and Accord wasn’t there but when I explained the problems folk have he understood.  As we are on it for a minimum of 5 years I feel we have the right to insist on a brand that doesn’t need extra meds for all the side effects! hugs xxx
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Just as a total aside, has anyone noticed hair getting curlier when on Letrozole? I didn’t have chemo or rads, just mx and implant which was repeated 30 hours later due to a haematoma, hair went a bit thinner, probably due to the stress of everything, but is definitely wavier/curlier than it was..... hugs xxx
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hi Coco, i agree with Pakamac, the exercises you are given will help regain normal movement of your affected arm, it’s necessary to do them properly and continue till the range is full, if you do have an implant or reconstruction, be guided by your BCN on going from the basic exercises to the more advanced ones! i had a mastectomy with implant at the beginning of April and have full movement in that shoulder now for a few weeks.  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Advice please! Cannot decide between LD flap and implant or expanders...

Posts.Content: Hi again, Coco,  I was an OT so therapy and rehab came pretty easy to me, I had full movement within days after my SNB which was a few weeks before the mastectomy, nodes were OK though they did double check in the big op, which possibly explains why it was a bit easier to exercise, who knows?!  I was told to gradually increase range even in the early days as movement was ok (and pain levels were easier than after the SNB and easily controlled by paracetamol), but supporting my (permanent) implant with the other hand and not to push much into discomfort for a while. I did do the exercises regularly, as suggested, three times a day, but easy to forget when they get easier, to be honest.  If you ensure you take pain relief a little before trying to do the exercises and rest for a good while afterwards, you'll find things improve surprisingly fast.  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Advice please! Cannot decide between LD flap and implant or expanders...

Posts.Content: Hi Minksy, im in a similar situation and now mostly wear padded bras as a result. I look ok in a bra but there’s a flat area centr to outside of my boob. The implant is a bit smaller than it might have been (surgeon admitted that) and so I’ve asked to go to our areas ‘reconstruction’ clinic to find out more.  Will be interested to read replies on here! hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, i did quite a bit of bra shopping and the softest by far were Sloggi zero feel, as they are padded they disguise the slightly odd, different shape I have post mx with implant, but not easy to put on as they are one piece, so if you’re slim hipped you can get them up that way but if your arm movement is good, (mine is) then over your head.  Thry aren’t cheap but wash and wear really well. I got mine from JL. They do ease off a bit too, I bought a generous size for sleeping which is now a bit looser.  Hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hello LH60,  I sympathise, you have a tricky decision but need to go with your gut instincts in the end. I had stage 2 invasive but no nodes involved and in the end, after the op when totally checked, some DCIS around it plus some small areas of calcification, and because of where it was, a mastectomy was just the best solution. But I wanted to have some sort of boob to wake up to, so my surgeon suggested a skin sparing mx and implant. I was lucky in that a skin scrape was possible and I am fairly happy with the result, I’ve a good cleavage if I wear a lowish cut top but do need a slightly padded bra as they are sisters but not twins!  Good wishes with your decision, remember you are a statistic of one, and the surgeon will be guided by your wishes. hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or re- excision?

Posts.Content: I found a Sloggi crop top type bra was incredibly soft, shaped rather than just stretchy, and all but seamless, very useful post mx when I needed to wear a bra at night. hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: I did wonder, assuming surgery is definitely needed, whether it would be possible nearer home where my husband could get (in his wheelchair) nearer the hospital. Parking at our main hospital, needless to say, is a nightmare, with the only suitable spaces for our high vehicle being up a long track way away, with building going on (so very dodgy for the wheelchair) So I phoned the BC nurse, who unfortunately said no it's only at the main hospital but for a mastectomy and implant (I think that's the way I'm going) it's only 2 nights in anyway. Guess we will cope somehow! Our daughter is determined to be with me Thursday, bless her.  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hello, I’m plucking up courage to write this too, I guess I’m a few days ahead of you in this waiting game. I’ve been there as I too found a lump, GP duly referred having given the ‘it is most likely fine’ talk, I got an appointment phoned to me and that was last Friday, 3 days after that phone call. I’ve duly had mammograms, ultrasound and biopsies, then in to see the surgeon.  Now I’ve had surgeries on that boob, in the days that they used to remove cysts and once also had a massive haematoma so there’s most likely lots of scar tissue. So I was dubious already as to what may happen. The surgeon told me I’d most likely be looking at a mastectomy, possibly chemo and/or radiotherapy. So I do have a bit more of an idea.... But the waiting till Pathology do all they need to with the biopsies is also ‘the pits’, so I really understand! I’ve been the carer for our daughter who had Hodgkin’s Lymphoma which proved refractory so she had an awful long wait till the magic word ‘remission’ occurred, in fact over 7 years. She’s doing fairly well now, but still has a very very low immune system. So my attitude is, if she can do it then of course so can I!  I’m also carer for hubs whose walking is very limited by spinal arthritis. Holding both your hands from afar, we can do it, we can deal with all that’s thrown at us!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi George, Haven’t seen you about so much recently!  Yes, it increases the big C incidence in my side of the family to more than 1in 2, father died aged 62 from lung cancer, brother has had bowel cancer but is ok now, and daughter had HL, surviving (so far!) so in my generation, assuming the surgeon is right, incidence is 2/2. Think that is more than our ‘share’!!!! My word for this? ‘BUMMER’!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: That made me grin and reach for the boxing gloves, Misty/Helen! I will keep them to hand from now on!  I confess to a very slight meltdown this morning, went to my usual yoga session, having told our lovely Sarah that I might be missing at times but please to hold my place as she has a waiting list already -it’s a new group! (and a brief reason) and this morning was all about ‘sun saluting’, ‘release’ and ‘grounding’ and when we eventually lay down to relax and meditate and listen to breathing my cheeks got a touch damp! I think till then I’d ‘just’ bottled it up, and not slept of course!  Bummer! Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, Yes, I’m glad about that outcome as of course we faced a good few years with daughter, hearing ‘get your affairs in order’, Hodgkin’s is generally 95% remission rate but hers was obstinate (like her, she says!) and they really were running out of ideas, it was only the third trial drug which was the one that worked!  Then the long long return from the donor bone marrow transplant; we really don’t know if her immune system will ever fully recover, they are already considering vaccination boosters as her levels are pretty low, letters and emails are flying between the Churchill and the Christie regularly trying to sort her out!  Bummer! Hugs xxx

However, I suspect mine was pretty obvious, and full mastectomy because of all the damage previous, it depends really on the hormone receptor type.  Holding hands...... We CAN do this! Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi again, i was only really offered a mx due to previous cyst and lump excisions (years ago they did remove cysts) and also where the cancer was in the breast.  I knew I wanted some form of reconstruction and due to my age and concern about the length of op and risks of two incisions, also that other ops might not be able to be done at my hospital, I wanted the cancer gone! So opted for the permanent implant, which my surgeon was happy to perform. I didn’t need chemo or radiotherapy.  Pain-wise, my team used a drip feed of local anaesthetic into the wound, which lasts a day or so, after that all I needed was regular paracetamol (and lots of rest)  hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi Henty, lots of sympathy! ........annnnddddd breathe! i had a mx with implant just over a year ago (on April 3rd) and yes, there were a few times I felt a bit abandoned. But I knew I had an excellent service in our small but very busy bc department, and knew a phone call to speak to the nurses would be answered, even if I had to leave a message.  I was lucky and didn’t need any other primary treatment, but have a further few years on hormone busting Letrozole. I’m feeling a similar anxiety as I’m coming up to annual appointments and mammogram in the next couple of days.  So, yes you can do this, yes it’s tough but this is a site where we all understand!  When you know a treatment plan you’ll have a lot less worry, but I guess you’ll still worry as cancer has this nasty, sneaky way of changing your life! sending hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Joint pains on AIs

Posts.Content: In Milton Keynes the BCU has been doing a one stop system where you even get an idea of possible diagnosis/treatment before pathology get a hold of biopsy samples.  They like to have control of it all without bothering local district nurse services, and want to expand, to include an extra surgeon and more staff to enable patients to get the best care possible.  To my knowledge this excellent unit has been doing this for 10-15 years now (had a colleague who needed it) and everyone going through it is treated so warmly (I’ve had wonderful caring personalised treatment  so far) and well.  I worry that this service, instead of being able to expand with the local population expansion (inevitable, it’s already beyond initial boundaries in all directions!) will get cut (informed by my own Smiley Surgeon, see Lisa Lynch ‘The C Word’ I have a signed copy of her book!) and already have written a scorcher of a letter about it to CEO forwarded by email to my lovely surgeon for her approval, then it will go very wide indeed! Expect press, MP, MofH etc....(but please let them not want to interview me yet, haha, I’m still laid up in my sickbed, only had surgery Tues AND Weds!)  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Cancer One Stop Shops Information

Posts.Content: I think GP’s are reluctant to think about cancer being a possibility in young people, blood cancers especially, many lymphoma patients are not diagnosed correctly for some time. Daughter actually changed GP surgery (on advice from her Physio) before she was diagnosed, aged 26, with Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Then it took a couple of months.... Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Great swan pic, Ronstar, reminds me of our BP pair of swans, they had 4 cygnets but sadly only 2 made it to adult size. It’s quite a lovely story, a number of years ago the RSPB released some sick and injured swans onto the small lake there and only one survived. He (we know that now!) has one very badly deformed leg and is not often far from the water. A couple of years ago another almost fully white swan joined him, she still had some grey feathers, but stayed. They chased off each Canada goose that tried to settle (there’s a small island) but tolerate the ducks, coot and moorhens, even the visiting heron. Then late last spring suddenly she had 4 wee fluffy fuzz balls in tow! And proved a brilliant mum, but one went early on (not sure how) and one later, by local foxes as one of the security chaps found the remains.  But the two still changing their feathers have stayed as if there’s enough food the adults don’t chase them off.  Hoping for more this year as I’ve seen the adults posing to each other! Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Cannon,  I suspect NHS staff are leaving a sinking ship to be honest, they have acknowledged that there are now too many closed beds as well as too few staff - at last!  I used to work in the NHS before retiring, have seen staffing levels go steadily down and down, slowly but steadily, to an extent where this becomes the new 'normal' and is on the verge of being unsafe.  It's really sad and I despair for the future. Before I had my kids (now 40 and 42) the mantra was to employ half of all school leavers to keep the NHS fully staffed. Did it happen? No, of course not!  But it's the only one we have, we need to look after it and use it wisely (which I do, but see it mis-used and abused so much)  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Yes, it’s fascinating work, and I’m currently the only lady Bombe operator regularly there, all the others are gents!  We hope sometime later this year to have a challenge from Poland, using one of their Enigmas. That WILL be  interesting! We’ve done 17 challenges so far, for real, 16 from GCHQ using their Enigma machine, and one from Paderborn in German, using Morse traffic as it was done in the 1940’s.....we’ve never taken longer than 5 hours to get the settings, and decode  the message. When you understand that the number of settings in a 3 rotor Enigma with a plug board is just under 159 million, million, million, then that’s not too bad!  Ha, I could go on.....!!!! Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Ha! My only walk today was to our local chippy at home, yes, I’m home again!  It was a decent journey apart from being stuck at zero mph on the M25 for about 45 minutes, never did find out quite why..... Got home, zoomed in and out with bags, boxes and cases, then grabbed my music, left hubs and shot off to the choir rehearsal I’d give apologies for, to be welcomed so warmly! Stayed on to work on our ‘Qui Sedes’ and then again in detail after two ladies had to leave....fixed another run of the alto ‘unison’ together with the cellist for Monday afternoon (Seaspirit will understand!) and then it’s dress rehearsal Tuesday, performance Thursday lunchtime, argh!  Then loads of washing.....almost dry, will put it all out again tomorrow since it seems the weather is going to be ok. Exhausted now, I was awake worrying about it all by 5.30am, possible Letrozole s/e’s too?  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Flossie,  I also had a long read of a US publication which said out of all mastectomy ops, the quickest emotional recovery was for ladies who had immediate reconstruction, of whatever type, but the best of all results mentally were for implants. I didn’t read that till well after I’d had mine but it confirmed what I already was thinking, it echoed that ‘waking to see two ‘bumps’ however different when you stand up! However, as for the speedy recovery, don’t forget I was a therapist so rehab comes very naturally to me, and I felt horrified when I was so weak, I worked hard at walking to build up stamina again, first walk (a long one so soon after the op) was to get out of the ward!!!  But, again, it has to be your decision!  Hugs xxx

So good to hear. Today all the walking I did was the full length of Bletchley Park and back at some speed, but I did stand much of the day anyway. Then this evening out to the concert tonight, which was lovely, nothing quite like a ‘live’ orchestral concert and even though they are amateurs they do get it all together in the performance!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Flossie, I’ve found loose-ish fitting stretchy trousers (emphasis on stretchy) are best for yoga, with a loose (fairly heavy knit so it drops into position again after your poses) tee shirt and/or long sleeved tee, take a cardigan or layers too as you will maybe start cold and warm up while you’re doing it. I wear socks at the moment but in summer months bare feet. You’ll need a yoga mat too. Some folk use a hard foam head block but I just take a small firm cushion. You might like a small fleece throw too if your teacher does a relaxation at the end.  Hope that helps?  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Sideways,  I had my mastectomy last April, had to have the op repeated 30 hours later due to haematoma developing. I still had quite a long walk out of the ward to the car the following day. I slept lots and rested lots, still pottered around home, but began very short walks outside about a week later, first of all ‘round the block’ then gradually further.  If you plan circular walks you can get home quickly if you find it too far. And remember that the anaesthetic takes a few weeks to fully leave your system, so feeling a bit wobbly is possibly that. But walking is a really good stamina building exercise post op, going further as and when you feel able. My walks are regularly 2 miles plus, sometimes further out into the country. Now that I’m well healed I often use trekking poles to help my leg joints, but I am 73!   Hope all goes well  hugs xxx

Oh, and said cyclist disappeared faster than he appeared, no way would he have been able to stop to find out if I was ok, he was going too fast to stop! What is worse, is the thought that at that speed he could have easily knocked someone over and badly hurt them!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi again Flossie,  I didn't spot your question about my implant!  I gather it makes for a longer op, and the drains are a bit more complex and my deep one stayed in for just over 2weeks. I'm fine, it's good to look down and see a 'bump' there when first waking. It is no way the same as the other one, I'm a bit old (73) and the other one drifts south with gravity. But in a bra (slightly padded) they look the same, twins. Otherwise they are definitely sisters!  And of course I do have a cleavage. The sensation is very odd, some parts feel relatively normal, some totally numb. I also have a slightly 'flat' spot to the left side where the two scars which got joined were pulled together a bit more than the rest, (have a small prosthesis to pop in a non padded bra)  will ask about that in my appointment (hard to imagine it's almost 3months now) in mid-July. I might also ask about hoiking the other one up a bit....not sure if they can or if it's really advised either.  Hugs xxx

Yes, max mobility was awarded after that!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome, Weejoyous, though sad you’ve needed to come here! i too came off HRT with a bump, and suspect a sudden stop might have been part of the problem, though mine was not for the bc issue, it was years before.  Yes the sweats were rough, but did ease off, I guess I just got used to it. Light clothing in layers, and the same with bedding really, you sort of get used to the ‘on/off’ routine. its got worse again for some of us as the medication reduces oestrogen even more for those of us with cancers that are affected by it. I’m thankful for that medication as it will hopefully keep me free now but it was hard work last hot spell when it had just got into my system.  A hand held rechargeable fan helps lots too, I’ve found, and that doesn’t impinge on anyone else much. Memory foam mattresses are comfortable but also render you feeling warm!  Hope you find remedies that work for you, hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Major issues with sleeping and night sweats

Posts.Content: Hi, forgive me for jumping in, but our daughter has had a donor bone marrow transplant and neutropenia and also fairly low white counts, too, was the name of the game for around 2 to 3 months, they said she could have bottled FIZZY water but not still….and that is, I think, standard transplant advice. Hope all goes well for you all Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: risk of infection- chemo

Posts.Content: I know I come as a carer from a different cancer, (so please forgive me jumping in here) but I find the 'brave' an unfortunate word chosen. I know it rhymes etc but having seen daughter lose her hair three times, the last possibly to lose her life too,(she didn't) as a result of treatment (a good third of patients undergoing a bone marrow transplant do not survive the first month) I've found I had to switch off whenever that advert showed.  I admire people like my good friend who have done this in the right way, realising it does in no way compare with treatment for cancer, and being filmed saying so. But for me, I think the adverts I have seen attempt to trivialise hair loss from chemo.  I wish it could be shown in a more sympathetic manner, not the laughing and joking in the advert. And maybe Macmillan could search a rhyming dictionary to replace the word 'brave' as although it's cold, odd and is lasting for a while, I still don't think the act of shaving is brave.  However, hugs to all who do it IN THE RIGHT SPIRIT and raise money.  And bigger hugs to all who are affected xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Helen,  I'm going to be a week behind you, going in on Easter Tuesday for a left mastectomy with immediate implant. I've had a SNB which came back negative so the surgeon is hopeful that it can be the permanent implant. She does a temporary if there's definitely got to be radiotherapy so that the rads don't damage the permanent one. But I'm lots older than you so hope my 'good' boob doesn't sag too much past the 'new' one!!!  I won't have a nipple but I gather you can get stick on ones! I've had two lots of surgery, she will use the scar above and the scar below the nipple as the centre line for a horizontal scar. I'm a B cup normally, but just bought a small-ish C cup duo pack of soft bras with plenty of support which also nicely misses my SNB site.  Everything crossed for us both!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: I saw your title and felt moved to answer, though my main experience right now is with our daughter, and having survived Hodgkin's Lymphoma after a long round of treatments. She was at diagnosis young, slim, fit, about to think about marathon running....ate (and eats) healthily too.  I think we eventually might find that it is a possible combination of genes and environment. It certainly wasn't her 'fault', but then she was around and very active at school when the Chernobyl cloud came over us here. Her consultant agreed it 'might' be a factor but nobody would ever know!
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Ive not even got anywhere near this stage but am taking them as I had insisted on a DEXA scan years ago, my mother had lost height and I too had lost a half inch. It proved I had low vit D3 levels, and osteopenia. They advised high vit D3 for 6 months and then regular calcichew vit d3 and further scan, then I'd got osteoporosis, and was put onto the Alendronic. That was 4 years ago, due another scan in a year even before I was diagnosed. However, now.......as my BC is hormone receptive I'm facing this even more. Argh!  Memo to self; do NOT fall over! But I'm naturally clumsy.  Hugs to all xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: Hi Resting,  You might find that the drain(s) need to stay longer than a couple of days, depending on your individual case and your procedure of course, I had two and went home after 2 nights with both still in (however, I am a ‘bit of a bleeder’ and bruise incredibly easily) in a little bag which was issued (made by the volunteers in the local charity) and my last was removed 16 days post op. I had a bit of a hiccup with the bleeding after my op and had to return to theatre for a further op (even including removing and re-doing the implant) 30 hours after the first, due to bleeding and clots. But all was fine afterwards even though the two ops left me a bit weak for a few days.  I’m sure all will go well for you, best wishes  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Sweendog,  Dr Google isn't that helpful to be honest so try not to dwell! I've found over the years, helping lymphoma patients that Google is really scary!  I kept away from all that and decided to have faith in my surgeon. (Hope it works!)  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: masterctomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi, I’ve been reading the Letrozole threads with interest as I began yesterday. I’m on many other meds too, including bispohosphanates (alendronic acid) and experiences joint and bone pain when I started that. I tackled that in a slightly different way, knowing that joint and bone pain with G-CSF gets treated successfully by lymphoma patients in the USA, by the antihistamine Claritin together with regular paracetamol, I gave it a try, and it helped. I had been used to walking several miles for pleasure, had been reduced to having pain walking out to the bus at the end of the road!  I carried on for 3 months gradually finding I could get back to walking for pleasure, and then ran out for 3 weeks, the pain increased so went back on them.  I had been off all non needed meds for a couple of weeks with the mx, but began the Claritin (generic Loratidine) the night before I began Letrozole and my fingers are crossed that it helps!  Just a bit of an idea!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi Edwina, this idea might possibly help you as it’s helping me? take the generic form of Claritin which is Loratidine, it’s a one a day antihistamine. They use it in the USA for bone and joint pain that arises with G-CSF used for white cell boosting. Nobody seems to know why or how it works, but it does help together with regular paracetamol. Might take a week or so to gradually help but I began when I started on Alendronic Acid. Even before the BC I had mild osteoporosis, and now being on Letrozole I suspect that’s not improving matters! (Need to book my next Dexa soon)  hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Don't think I can cope on Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a left skin sparing mastectomy with immediate implant at the start of April this year. Although I’m now 73 I just couldn’t face waking and seeing a wonky chest, and now have a decent cleavage. A longer op with a DIEP wasn’t really an option as I was concerned about infection possibility though it would have been a good way to get a flatter tummy!  I was lucky in that I’d had a positive-free mammogram so to be sure a SNB before my surgery, and yes my nodes were free, so no radiotherapy indicated, HER2 neg so no chemo, just  hormone-busting Letrozole as mine was OR+ Recovery pretty ok though I did have to have repeat surgery the following day as I bled therefore had blood clots to clear, even behind the implant so it was all re-done. So the first few days I did feel a bit washed out. Otherwise all good, they use glue in my unit rather than dressings so I was able to shower once home, though had to clear space on a shelf for the drains!  Hope all the stories help you in your decision, best wishes whatever you decide it has to be right for you!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Shout out to lovely Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi, like Helen I had a mx with implant in the beginning of April, in a bra it looks great, which I suspect is what they like to see. I was told at my 3 month check up that a good 6 months further on is when they will consider any adjustments needed. My new boob is numb in parts, but some of that is improving as the nerves grow back, it’s also a bit smaller, perkier but with a flat-ish spot and no nipple, but I’m reasonably ok with it. Surgeon said she could reduce the other but I’d rather she augmented the new one to remove the flat area. I’m not bothered about nipple loss, usually wear slightly padded bras anyway. hope that helps a bit?  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Advice on reconstructive surgery and reduction of good breast

Posts.Content: Hello,  Like Flossie, I am sure that whatever you decide will be right for you, it’s a tough decision but you can do it! just thought I’d post my take on my bc. I had little option because of site and status than to go for a mx. Fortunately we’d booked a few days away and the mammogram suggested no node affected, so the surgeon decided on a SNB first then if all seemed ok a mx a few weeks later.  Somehow I just knew I wanted an implant, I had realised a reconstruction was a much bigger op and at 73 felt it wasn’t really an option but I wanted to preserve a ‘bit of a figure’ if I could. Surgeon happy to help, and suggested that as the SNB came back negative too, we went for the permanent implant.  Its not bad, a bit smaller than other boob with a flat area but I’m looking into whether to think about any augmentation, probably won’t but want to know what’s involved. In a decent bra I’ve a good cleavage and you’d never know!  Take your time, do what’s right for you, take care and do use this group, it’s so supportive! hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hello Maggie, Saw your post and felt you needed rapid reassurance (I'm usually lurking in the blood cancer groups, but do spot things to answer, forgive me for jumping in here! )  YES it DOES exist! They call it chemo related cognitive disorder or some such name. It does ease, and you can use all sorts of ideas if it is bad, such as writing stuff down, post-it notes and so on....our daughter had 7 years of chemo and trial drugs, hers got pretty bad. She copes by asking if folk could confirm in emails, texts and so on, and keeps a very organised diary!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Maggie, give yourself time, it may take easily as long as the general post chemo fatigue, might be longer. However, think about 'exercising' your mind, and stay calm while you try to remember stuff..... I'm sure it will slowly improve!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Just hope you feel reassured......on line scrabble sounds a great idea, or you can even play against yourself, lol!  Take it steady and don't panic!  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hi all, the battle of the Letrozole brands rumbles on.....I too have a male GP but did have an appointment with him for another matter and explained that differing brands of L seem to cause different s/e’s and would he be prepared to put ‘Accord’ on my repeat script, which he duly did. I’ve plainly refused a different brand at the pharmacy (they can re-use meds’ as long as you’ve not left the store, another reason for collecting it yourself and checking!) and they re-ordered Accord for me. Interestingly the regular but part time pharmacist in there knows this happens with different generics of Tamoxifen and agrees that it can therefore happen with other meds, and as she says, if you’re going to be on it for years then stick to the brand that seems to suit you!  Hope you continue getting what works for you hugs xxx
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Hi PollyMac, Please don’t think it’s your age, I’m now 73 and they still did the ‘one stop shop’ for me when I was seen within the fortnight, mammograms, ultrasound scan and biopsies, then seeing the surgeon who was pretty positive it would mean a mastectomy even though results took a further 2 weeks, so I was prepared. I might be lucky as the breast unit in our local hospital is EXCELLENT!  So I suspect it doesn’t bode well on your local hospital, NHS or private.  Like LeoLady, I think complaints may be in order, that’s not the right way to treat you, especially as you, via your insurance, are paying to go private!

Posts.Title: No tears left

Posts.Content: Hi Noswad, mine, too, was grade 2 Er+ and I later found out HER2- so no chemo was indicated. I had a holiday booked so my surgeon suggested a sentinel node biopsy as it looked on the mammogram that it hadn’t even got to lymph nodes, and then a mastectomy (with implant, temporary if it was in my lymph nodes, permanent if it wasn’t) after my holiday.  I was ok, fortunately and had the op with permanent implant (a node was checked during that surgery too) and now take what I call hormone busting, or anti-hormone treatment! That’s for 5 years.  My team are caring, thorough and ultra professional and I have tremendous faith in them, as I’ve had a few alarms and they’ve sorted me out calmly and reassuringly each time. They are incredibly busy but always find time.  I hope you have a similar experience (though not with any blips!) and sail through all this  hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Grade 2 ER pos ductal

Posts.Content: Hi Lellyv, its worth asking your hospital plus your local surgery if there are any volunteer drivers? You would have to pay fuel costs but I’m sure it would be far better and cheaper than taxis.  Do phone Macmillan as they’ve got a finance advice section who can help with all sorts of stuff, 0808 808 0000.  Also if your neighbourhood has a dedicated Facebook page then you might be able to appeal for help there?  Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: Hi LottieB, I’m 73 now and yes, still get incredibly scared at times!  I was one of those missed by routine scans and found my lump myself, yes it was invasive ductal but HER2- and there were no nodes involved, ER+ though, 8/8 so after my mastectimy I got put on Letrozole and am fighting a few aches with it.....but grateful that I’m here and can still support my daughter (though for a week or so there was a role reversal when she came to help me -see my profile!)  I don’t think anyone of our age group DOESN’T feel scared when they hear the word cancer, to be honest, we all have memories of it taking some of our relatives and friends too early.  Hugs xxx

At least by doing all I can to counteract the nasty side effects (Glucosamine with chondroitin, Loratidine, and exercise as sensibly as possible; plus a challenging volunteering role learning new stuff all the time) I feel I’m trying my very best. I also ensure I stick to the same brand each time.  Hugs xxx

Posts.Title: letrozole side effects - sudden onset?

Posts.Content: An interesting subject!  I insisted on a Dexa scan way back, my mother had lost height and I was starting to. It showed possible osteopenia and suggested my D3 level was checked. Had the blood test and within the day, result showed low levels. A prescription for high strength capsules followed, for a limited time. Then a prescription for Adcal D3, due to nausea I never managed to take the twice daily dose.  Following that, the next Dexa showed mild osteoporosis (and I had broken a wrist in a fall on ice) so got prescribed Alendronic Acid. I then found a better source of D3 and have been taking them (no nausea) dosage was checked out and advised by GP.  I will be interested in results of next Dexa, due in October. And all this was way before my bc diagnosis.  But yes, due to the winter lack of sun and our reluctance to bare flesh in the coldest months of the year (!) most people in the UK are deficient in vit D. I do try to go out with bare arms (apparently all that’s needed) for 15 minutes when it’s warm enough and sunny.  Hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, please don’t be scared! We are all here to help you! Mine too was IDC Er + and HER2 negative, and had a sentinel node biopsy first as we’d got some holiday booked. It wasn’t in my nodes so due to the position of the cancer, I just then had a mastectomy, (and implant) no need for chemo (due to the HER status) and no need for radiotherapy as it hadn’t got into the nodes. I’m 73 though (but fit and active and a carer) which is maybe why they also decided on less invasive treatment. But I am taking meds (Letrozole) to reduce oestrogen.  Hope you too are helped easily  hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Caption Competition

Posts.Content: Hi ladies,  ive been on Letrozole 6 months plus now, and yes, the problems do seem to build till around this sort of time frame. My BCN did warn me that this might be the case, so I decided to stay on the Claritin (put myself on it for the aches that I got when taking Alendrobic Acid for osteoporosis) or rather, the generic form, Loratidine. I gather that sticking to the same brand of Letrozole can be helpful, I’m on Accord and my pharmacy have this listed so will supply me with the same each time.ive also put myself on Glucosamine and chondroitin, with approval of my BCN.  i Have to agree, it might be the effect of the Letrozole but might ‘just’ be the reduced oestrogen levels? Who knows?  My hair thinned too but as I had very thick hair which needed regular thinning that didn’t worry me overmuch. It’s now a bit thicker again, so I wonder if it was the shock of having cancer and three operations within a month (my mx developed a haematoma so was re-done 30 hours later including re-doing the implant)  i too have read that similar AI’s have similar side effects, it might be that swapping is like jumping out of the frying pan into the fire?! So I’m sticking with it in the knowledge that it’s preventing recurrence/secondary problems!  Hugs xxx

Posts.Title: Dreaded Mastectomy!

Posts.Content: Hi Kathleen, so sorry you’re struggling, but by all accounts you’re on the best brand!  I had issues with Alendronic Acid ( had mild osteoporosis even before the cancer poop) and decided to try Loratidine (Claritin is the non generic name) which is one a day. It helped so I’ve continued. I also talked to BCN about maybe adding Glucosamine and Chondroitin when I noticed aches were getting worse with lovely Letrozole (but my bc is 8/8 so I will battle on!) and ive found things did improve once my body got used to it all, plus I try and walk 2-3 miles 2-3 times a week as well.  I know it’s more expense, as GP’s don’t prescribe these antihistamines or the G&C any more, but if it helps then I will carry on! And bc brings expense anyway, what with having to buy bras etc.... hope you find something that helps.... hugs xxx

Posts.Content: Hi again Kathleen,  yes I too hated the calcichew, but as my diet is reasonably ok in calcium, I just needed the D3, I found a source of D3 (Costco) and talked to my GP about dosage, he was happy I was getting sufficient and so I take that instead. In fact the calcichew made my indigestion so bad I didn’t ever manage to night time dose anyway, so I’m probably getting more D3 than I ever did! It’s now coming up to my 5 year Dexa scan this year so it will be interesting to see how things are. I’ve got a bad scoliosis so they can only measure my hips.  Do check with your BCN before embarking on any changes in meds!  Hugs xxx
